case_data.chief_complaint: Recurrent episodes of palpitations and breathlessness on exertion for 3 months
case_data.initial_presentation: A 42-year-old homemaker from Nagpur presents to the cardiology OPD with complaints of episodic palpitations lasting 15-30 minutes, occurring 2-3 times per week for the past 3 months, along with gradually worsening breathlessness on exertion. She also reports a recent episode of transient weakness in her right hand lasting 10 minutes that resolved spontaneously.

stages.info: Palpitations are episodic, irregular, lasting 15-30 minutes, sometimes associated with mild lightheadedness. Breathlessness has progressed from NYHA class I to II over 3 months — now gets dyspneic climbing one flight of stairs. Reports one episode of transient right-hand weakness and numbness 2 weeks ago lasting ~10 minutes, spontaneously resolved (TIA). She had rheumatic fever at age 14 with joint pains, treated at a local hospital — no follow-up since. No chest pain. No orthopnea or PND currently. No hemoptysis. She is a non-smoker, non-alcoholic, vegetarian. Has 2 children, both normal deliveries. Last delivery was 10 years ago. Family history: mother has diabetes, father had a stroke at 65. Not on any medications. No history of thyroid disease.

Patient is of average build, BMI 24. Mild malar flush noted. No pallor, cyanosis, or clubbing. JVP: Normal. Pulse: Irregularly irregular, rate ~92/min, variable volume. BP equal in both arms. CVS: Loud S1, opening snap followed by a low-pitched mid-diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex best heard in left lateral decubitus with the bell, accentuated pre-systolically. Loud P2. No parasternal heave. Apex beat: Tapping, not displaced. Lungs: Fine bibasal crepitations, more on the right side. Abdomen: Soft, no hepatosplenomegaly. No pedal edema. CNS: No focal neurological deficit at present.

ECG: Atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate (~94 bpm), no ST-T changes, P-mitrale absent (AF), left atrial abnormality pattern in prior sinus rhythm ECGs unavailable. CXR PA view: Straightening of left heart border, double density sign at right heart border, prominent upper lobe pulmonary veins (cephalization), Kerley B lines at both lung bases, no pleural effusion. 2D Echocardiography: Mitral valve thickened and doming ('hockey-stick' pattern), commissural fusion, mitral valve area 1.1 cm² by planimetry (severe MS), mean gradient 14 mmHg, Wilkins score 9/16, mild MR (grade I), left atrium severely dilated (LA diameter 5.4 cm), LVEF 58%, moderate pulmonary hypertension (PASP 52 mmHg), no LA appendage thrombus on TTE. TEE: Confirms no LA/LAA thrombus. Dense spontaneous echo contrast (smoke) in LA. CBC: Hb 12.1, WBC 7,200, Platelet 2.1 lakh. TSH: 3.8 mIU/L (normal). INR: 1.0 (not anticoagulated). CRP: 4 mg/L. ASO titre: Negative. Renal and liver function: Normal. HbA1c: 5.6%.

case_data.diagnosis: Severe rheumatic mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation and recent transient ischemic attack (cardioembolic), candidate for percutaneous transvenous mitral commissurotomy (PTMC)
differentials: Left atrial myxoma causing mitral valve obstruction
Mitral annular calcification with functional stenosis
learning_points: Rheumatic mitral stenosis remains the most common valvular heart disease in India, often presenting decades after the initial episode of rheumatic fever. A history of joint pains in childhood should raise suspicion.

Atrial fibrillation in mitral stenosis significantly increases thromboembolic risk (up to 5-fold). Anticoagulation with warfarin (target INR 2-3) is mandatory; DOACs are NOT recommended in moderate-severe MS.

Wilkins echocardiographic score (leaflet mobility, thickening, calcification, subvalvular involvement; each scored 0-4) ≤8 favors PTMC. A score of 9 is borderline — PTMC can still be considered if MR is ≤ mild and there is no LA thrombus.

TIA in a young woman with no conventional stroke risk factors should prompt evaluation for a cardiac embolic source — atrial fibrillation with valvular heart disease is a high-risk combination requiring urgent anticoagulation.
case_data.atypical_features: The transient neurological episode (TIA) as a presenting feature in a relatively young woman without conventional stroke risk factors creates a diagnostic challenge. The AF was not previously diagnosed, and the rheumatic heart disease was undetected for nearly 28 years. The borderline Wilkins score of 9 adds a management decision dilemma — whether to proceed with PTMC or refer for surgical mitral valve replacement. The presence of dense spontaneous echo contrast without formed thrombus requires careful TEE evaluation before any intervention.
